title: Steph & Dom solve your sex, love & life troubles: Our counsellor always sides with my husband
text:
TV’s Steph and Dom Parker, 52 and 54, draw on their 21 years of marriage to solve your relationship problems . . .

Q: My husband and I have started seeing a couple’s counsellor. We’re both in our late 40s and have been married for more than 20 years.

Things haven’t been right for a while. The spark has gone out and we never spend quality time together. I just feel miserable, so I suggested we tried counselling. He took some persuading. However, it’s not gone the way I hoped it would. For starters, I cannot stand the female counsellor — she is much harsher on me than my husband. She always seems to take his side. It makes me so angry. Part of the problem is I feel put upon by him — and now by her, too. Last week, after four sessions, I tried to bring it up with my husband, but he said I was imagining things.

An anonymous reader asked TV's Steph and Dom Parker for advice on seeing a counsellor with her husband (file image)

No surprise, he is finding it extremely helpful, and wants to carry on seeing her.

I don’t know what to do.

STEPH SAYS: It’s a scenario many of us know well — you’ve been married for ever, the spark has gone, you’re not enjoying each other’s company and life feels a bit bleak.

There are countless couples around the country who have felt like that, who have spent all their time being focused on getting to the next stage of life, on living not on loving.

It’s so easy to forget about the person next to you when you’re busily getting on with things, so good for you for being pro-active and trying to improve your relationship.

And congratulations on getting your husband to go with you for counselling. Persuading a man to agree to see a therapist is incredibly hard — so well done to you!

Seeking marriage counselling is, in my book, always a good thing. But, and it’s a big but, it is often recommended that you meet a couple of therapists before you commit to your choice. They are people, after all, and they have to be a good fit for you — both of you.

Perhaps what happened is that you went along and, grateful that you had managed to get your husband there, simply ticked the box and showed up to your next appointment without really considering if the woman you were meeting was the best person to help.

Steph (pictured with Dom) told the reader to book a session to see their counsellor alone, as an opportunity to express her feelings

And who knows, maybe she has formed too close a bond to your husband? Maybe she really does favour him? Maybe he even likes her a little too much, too — I can’t know because I’m not in the room with the three of you. But what I do know is that you seem very unhappy. You don’t like him. You don’t like her. Might it be that you don’t like yourself very much either?

Are you cross with yourself because your relationship is not working? Perhaps you’re terrified things might be ending?

I think you have to be very honest with yourself as to why you don’t like her.

Are you sure it’s not you, you hate?

Is she simply the scapegoat for your fear and insecurity? The force of your feelings makes me think that, deep down, you still love your husband.

So how to solve this? Well, I think it would be a good idea to book in for a session alone with her. Tell her what you’re feeling. She won’t be the first — or the last — counsellor to hear this, I’m sure. Talk it through with her and see if there’s any truth in what you’re saying. Then decide how to proceed.

If this is your problem, then you must stop beating up everyone else. If it’s not? Well, there are plenty of counsellors out there, but only one husband.

DOM SAYS: Well, I must say, I’ve never come across this one before.

And I’d like to say ‘thank you’ for writing in, as I suspect it took a bit of courage. This is quite something to admit to.

I’d also like to congratulate you on taking the massive step of going to couples’ counselling after 20 years of marriage, as I’m sure that wasn’t easy either.

Whenever people do go for counselling, I believe the general recommendation is that the therapist should be carefully chosen and there should be an initial meeting to see whether you get along.

Dom (pictured) urged the reader to consider if her counsellor is telling an unpalatable truth or two

After all, it is perfectly possible that you just don’t like the cut of someone’s jib, and there’s nothing wrong with that!

So it’s a bit of a shame that this didn’t happen.

But, having chosen this person, and committed to this path, it seems only correct to try to make things work.

One thing I feel is important to point out here is that, in general, counsellors are people who are professional and well-behaved. So it does seem unlikely that she would be unfairly siding with your husband and picking on you!

You may not want to hear this, but I suspect it’s far more likely that, having chosen to go and do this — and convinced your husband to do it — you simply don’t like the direction things are taking.

You say in your letter that you feel ‘put upon’ by your husband and now by the counsellor, too.

I know that finger-pointing is not what’s supposed to happen in these sessions.

The bitterest pill is the best remedy

But, fundamentally, someone is going to be told they’re not trying hard enough. That they’re not putting in enough effort. And, dare I say it? Perhaps you’re being told that the problems in your marriage are more your fault than your husband’s?

My guess is you don’t like what’s been said and you’ve simply taken umbrage.

I can see how it would happen, especially if you feel your husband is just sitting there, smugly.

Of course, only you will know deep down in your heart whether this is true.

But I urge you to ask yourself if you’re really sure this woman is not telling you an unpalatable truth or two.

If so, then grow up and don’t sling the baby out with the bath water.

You can’t stand her? Good! She’s probably telling you things you need to hear!

Don’t forget — it’s often said that the bitterest pill is the best remedy.

If you have a question you’d like Steph and Dom to tackle, write to: stephanddom@dailymail.co.uk
description: An anonymous reader asked TV's Steph and Dom Parker for advice on visiting a counsellor who always seems to take her husband's side. She says her husband think she's imagining things.
authors: Steph And Dom Parker For The Daily Mail
